translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Ultimate End
Wandering about in views, he thinks: “This is the ultimate truth!”
Whatever a person does in the world,

analyzed: hīnā ati aññe tatas sabbam āha
translated: He thinks it’s the best, and so he says it’s all
So he doesn’t go beyond disputes.
Whatever benefit he sees in views,
Whether seen, heard, or thought,
He grasps just that,
And thinks everything else is inferior.

analyzed: tam vā api gantham kusalāḥ vadanti
translated: The wise say that’s a fetter,

original: Yaṁ nissito passati hīnamaññaṁ;🔽Tasmā hi diṭṭhaṁ va sutaṁ mutaṁ vā,
analyzed: yam nissitaḥ passati  tasmā hi diṭṭham sutam mutam vā
translated: Because he thinks what he’s attached to is inferior to everything else.🔽So a monk shouldn’t rely on what’s seen, heard, or thought,
Or on virtue and practice.
He shouldn’t form a view in the world
Either through knowledge or through virtue.
He shouldn’t think himself equal,

analyzed: hīnaḥ na maññetha visesi vā api
translated: Inferior, or superior.
Giving up and not grasping at self,

original: Ñāṇepi so nissayaṁ no karoti;🔽Sa ve viyattesu na vaggasārī,🔽Diṭṭhimpi so na pacceti kiñci.
analyzed: ñāṇe api saḥ nissayam no karoti  sa ve viyattesu na vagga sārī  diṭṭhim pi so na pacceti kiñci
translated: He doesn’t rely on knowledge.🔽He doesn’t side with any faction in disputes,🔽And he doesn’t accept any view.
He who has no wish in either direction
for existence here or in the next world.
He has no home anywhere,
he has cut off all attachments to ideas.

original: Tassīdha diṭṭhe va sute mute vā,
analyzed: tassa idha diṭṭhe va sute mute vā
translated: Here, in what is seen, heard, or sensed,
he has no notion, not even the slightest.
What view could one have of that brahmin,
who does not accept any view?
He does not accept, he does not prefer,
he does not approve of ideas.
The brahmin is not led by virtue,
he has gone beyond, he does not return.
The Discourse on the Ultimate End, the Fifth.
